quiz.title: Unit 12: AP Microeconomics (Quiz 8)
quiz.subtitle: Taste Shifts, Expectations, and Inferior Goods
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Demand/Supply Shifts, Future Expectations, Income Elasticity

questions.question: Suppose consumer tastes shift toward the consumption of apples. Which of the following statements is an accurate description of the impact of this event on the market for apples?
options: There is an increase in the quantity demanded of apples along the demand curve and in the supply for apples.
There is an increase in the demand and supply of apples.
There is an increase in the demand for apples and a decrease in the supply of apples.
There is a decrease in the quantity demanded of apples along the demand curve and an increase in the supply for apples.
There is an increase in the demand for apples and an increase in the quantity supplied of apples along the supply curve.
questions.explanation: Increased taste for apples shifts demand right. Higher demand raises price, which increases quantity supplied (movement along supply curve). Supply does not shift unless a supply determinant changes.

questions.question: Suppose both buyers and sellers of wheat expect the price of wheat to rise in the near future. What would we expect to happen to the equilibrium price and quantity in the market for wheat today?
options: The impact on both price and quantity is ambiguous.
Price will decrease; quantity is ambiguous.
Price will increase; quantity will decrease.
Price will increase; quantity is ambiguous.
Price will increase; quantity will increase.
questions.explanation: Buyers expect higher future prices → demand increases today (shift right). Sellers expect higher future prices → supply decreases today (shift left). Both shifts increase price today. Quantity depends on relative shift magnitudes, so quantity change is ambiguous.

questions.question: An inferior good is one for which an increase in income causes a(n)
questions.explanation: Inferior good: demand decreases when income rises (negative income elasticity). Supply is not directly affected by changes in consumer income.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of demand/supply interactions, expectations, and good classifications.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review effects of tastes, expectations, and income changes.
scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding; focus on how expectations shift demand/supply and income elasticity.
scoreMessages.0: Review: demand vs. quantity demanded, supply vs. quantity supplied, and inferior/normal goods.
